name: Traces and Threads of Personal Archives
description:
Image Credits: Untitled (Seated Portrait of Three Siblings), Suresh Punjabi, India, 1985-1986, Celluloid negative, PHY.12217

Do you have a photograph of your grandparents you can’t stop looking at? A coin that was passed down to you? A handwritten letter from a loved one?

Bring an object (letter, photograph, etc) and join us for a discussion on how to care for, and preserve them. Then, participate in a fun exercise and a mapping session where we exchange stories and memories inspired by each object. Facilitated by our summer interns, Jyestha and Rihana, this session starts with a walkthrough of our Sasken digital exhibition, Museum of Memories.

Do note: Please do not bring hazardous or high-risk objects.

This session is conducted as part of our engagements for the MAP Youth Collective. The MAP Youth Collective is a community for young people (18-25 year olds) to engage with the arts and culture sector. The collective is for, of and by young people — to explore our shared identities and interests through art.

name: Draw with PencilJam
description:
If you find joy in drawing intricate patterns or practicing observational sketching, we invite you to be part of this relaxed and inspiring session. Set against the backdrop of the museum’s vibrant exhibits, this gathering offers an open, creative space for artists of all skill levels. Whether you're looking to unwind through sketching, discover new perspectives, or simply enjoy the act of drawing in a shared environment, this is a chance to slow down and truly observe the world around you. Connect with fellow art lovers, exchange ideas, and share your work in an informal, supportive setting that celebrates creativity in all its forms.

You will need to carry your own:
- Sketchbook or A4 paper
- Pencil (wood or mechanical) and eraser
- Gel pens or fineliners for outlining
- Colour brush pens, sketch pens, or colour pencils (no wet media)

name: Maadathy - An Unfairy Tale
description:
India is a land of Subaltern deities, where each deity has a unique legend and these legends are often interwoven with socio-historic tropes of India.

The Puthirai vannaar  are a Dalit caste group known as the 'unseeable', in southern India. Their forced-occupation is to wash the clothes of other Dalits, the dead, and menstruating women. This film explores the tale of a young girl who grew up in the Puthirai vannaar caste group and how she came to be immortalised as their local deity, Maadathy.

Do note: This is a Tamil language film and is subtitled in English.

name: Led by Curator
description:
Join Arnika Ahldag, Director-Exhibitions & Curation at MAP, as she takes you through a guided walk of our newest exhibition, Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar. An artist who felt deeply, Ram Kumar was shaped by the world around him. From an economist, to a writer, to an artist — his methods of expression were as layered and manifold as the emotions his art inspires.

We invite you to come, linger, and contemplate through the mesmerising artworks of one of India’s most renowned modernists on the occasion of his centenary year.

name: Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar in ISL
description:
Join us for a special Indian Sign Language interpreted walkthrough of Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar. The exhibition invites visitors to pause and reflect, observe and be inspired. Come on a journey of introspection through the mesmerising artworks and evocative letters of Ram Kumar, one of India’s most renowned modernists on the occasion of his centenary year.

The exhibition is accompanied by two activities that create a deeper engagement with the art on display. The Writing Table gives audiences a chance to write a letter to themselves, loved ones, strangers, or even a city through a set of prompts. Family Label facilitates an exploration of abstract art by allowing visitors to look at artworks and creating a label on what they think the artwork means, or what they see or feel when faced with an abstract artwork.

Shape of a Thought also features the film ‘The Spaces in Between’ by Naveed Mulki. The film explores letter exchanges between Ram Kumar and his friend and the many conversations they have on life, art and the world.

name: Ticket Tika Chaap
description:
From dancing elephants and beloved deities, to steamships and radiators, textile labels showcased a variety of captivating imagery. These labels arrived in Indian markets in the thousands, stuck on yards upon yards of cotton fabric manufactured in the mills of Britain (and India), and sold in Indian and global markets. They wove desire, memory, and meaning into the act of purchase.

The exhibition, Ticket Tika Chaap, explores these textile labels known as tikats (tickets), tikas or chaaps, and their art-historical and commercial significance, as perhaps the earliest forms of branding and advertisement, in India.

Please note: This guided walk, will be conducted in Kannada by Rajesh from the MAP Team.

name: Led by MAP Founder
description:
Join us for a special walkthrough of Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar led by MAP’s Founder, Abhishek Poddar. In this reflective walkthrough, he shares personal insights into the life and work of Ram Kumar, drawing from his own close relationship with the artist.

Come and discover how Ram Kumar’s evocative letters and stirring paintings come together in the exhibition, and how his legacy lives on.

name: Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar with Curator
description:
Led by Priya Chauhan, curator of Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar, this guided walk gives audiences a peek into the curatorial process of the exhibition. Join us to gain a deep understanding of the artist and his journey to becoming one of India’s most iconic modernist voices

The exhibition invites visitors to pause and reflect, observe and be inspired. Experience the profound inner world of Ram Kumar, as we mark the centenary this extraordinary artist.
